revisions.rev:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} '''â¬2 commemorative coins''' are special [[euro coins]] minted and issued by member states of the [[eurozone]] since 2004 as [[legal tender]] in all eurozone member states. The coins typically [[Commemorative coin|commemorate]] the anniversaries of historical events or draw attention to current events of special importance. As of 2011, a hundred and four variations of â¬2 commemorative coins have been [[Mint (coin)|minted]] â six in 2004, eight in 2005, seven in 2006, twenty in 2007 (including the thirteen versions of the common issue), ten in 2008, twenty-five in 2009 (including the sixteen versions of the common issue), twelve in 2010 and sixteen in 2011. The â¬2 commemorative coins have become [[collectible]]s, but are different from [[Euro gold and silver commemorative coins|commemorative coins with a face value higher than â¬2]], which are officially designated as "collector coins" and usually made of precious metals.{{cite web | author=[[European Commission]] | url=http://ec.europa.eu/economy_finance/the_euro/notes_coins8787_en.htm | title= Euro coins | accessdate=2008-09-22 }} Only the country sides of the coins may be changed; the common side may not. In 2007 and 2009, all countries released common commemorative coins, though [[Cyprus]], [[Estonia]] and [[Ireland]] have not released any independently. [[Luxembourg]] and [[Finland]] are the only countries to have released commemorative coins every year. The number of commemorative coins is limited to one per country per year and to 5 percent of the total output. Limits on the designs are also in place to ensure uniformity. ==Regulations and restrictions== The basis for the commemorative coins is derived from a decision of the [[European Council]], which allowed changing the national [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] sides of euro coins from 1 January 2004 onwards.{{cite journal | title=OJ 2003/C 247/03 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=15 October 2003 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:C:2003:247:0005:0006:EN:PDF }} However, a number of recommendations and restrictions still apply. Two restrictions concern the design. Euro coins must still have a common reverse side, so only the national obverse sides may be changed. Also, the standard national obverse sides ''per se'' should not be changed before 2008 at the earliest, unless the [[head of state]] depicted on some of the coins changes before then. (This clause already came into effect for [[Monaco]] and the [[Vatican City]], whose heads of stateâ[[Rainier III, Prince of Monaco|Rainier III]] and [[Pope John Paul II]] respectivelyâdied in 2005 and whose national obverse sides were changed for 2006.) Further regulations restrict the frequency and number of commemorative coin issues. Each member state shall only issue one commemorative coin per year, and it shall only be denominated as a â¬2 coin. The total number of such coins put into circulation per year should not surpass the higher of the following two numbers:{{cite web | author=[[General Secretariat of the Council of the European Union]] | date=2003-11-17 | url=http://register.consilium.europa.eu/pdf/en/03/st14/st14941.en03.pdf | title=Draft Council conclusions on the Commission Recommendation on a common practice for changes in the design of national obverse sides of euro circulation coins | accessdate=2008-07-07 | format=PDF }} * 0.1 % of the total number of â¬2 coins put into circulation by all members of the eurozone. This limit can exceptionally be increased to up to 2.0 per cent if the coin commemorates a very important and noteworthy event; in this case, the member state issuing this higher number of coins should refrain from putting any commemorative coins into circulation for the following four years. * 5.0 % of the total number of â¬2 coins put into circulation by the member state issuing the â¬2 commemorative coin. Another decision added two more guidelines regarding the design of the coins. The state issuing a coin should in some way clearly be identified on the obverse side, either by stating the full name or a clearly identifiable abbreviation of it; and neither name nor the denomination of the coin should be repeated on the obverse, as it is already featured on the common reverse side.{{cite journal | title=OJ 2005/L 186/01 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union | date=18 July 2005 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2005/l_186/l_18620050718en00010002.pdf | format=PDF }} These restrictions do not apply retroactively; only new designsâthe national obverse sides for regular issues of states newly joining the euro or of eurozone states which change their design, and â¬2 commemorative coins issued from 2006 onwardsâare subject to them. However, the five countries whose designs violated the first update to the rules ([[Austria]], [[Belgium]], [[Finland]], [[Germany]] and [[Greece]]) initially were assumed to have to change their design in the near future, which [[Finland]] did for 2007{{cite press release | title=Designs of euro coins will be amended in 2007 | publisher=[[Bank of Finland]] | date=2006-12-27 | url=http://www.bof.fi/en/suomen_pankki/ajankohtaista/tiedotteet/2006/tiedote33_2006.htm | accessdate=2007-04-22 }} and [[Belgium]] for 2008. Another decision changed the rules again:{{cite journal | title=OJ 2009/L 9/52 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union | date=14 January 2009 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2009:009:0052:0055:EN:PDF | format=PDF }} * The twelve stars of the [[European Union]] surrounding the coin designs need to surround all of the coin design elements, including year marks, mint marks and the name of the country. The stars have to appear in the same way as they are aligned on the flag of the European Union. (These recommendations are not currently fulfilled by the Dutch, Italian and Luxembourgish coins.) * The design of euro coins may not be changed except for two specific circumstances: ** If a coin design is in violation of the recommendations, it may be updated to bring it into line with them. (This applies to Austria, Germany, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands.) ** If a coin design depicts a head of state, it may be updated: ::# every fifteen years to bring it into line with the head of state's current appearance; ::# if the head of state abdicates or dies. However, temporary heads of state may not be used as a reason for changing the design; instead a â¬2 commemorative coin (potentially a second â¬2 commemorative coin) will be allowed to be issued. * The edge lettering of commemorative coins has to be the same as the one on the regular coins. (These provisions forced Belgium to change its design back to show the original portrait of its monarch, because the 2008 update to follow the recommendations also updated the portrait, which was against the rules. The Belgian coins from 2009 onwards show the original royal portrait of 1999, but otherwise keep the new 2008 coin design as far as the country identification and year mark are concerned. These provisions additionally prohibit further ''[[sede vacante]]'' sets of coins by the Vatican City, allowing only commemorative coins for such occasions.) Slovakia, Slovenia and Spain were the states which were in breach of these new guidelines. Spain updated their design from 2010 onwards to meet the new rules, leaving Austria, Germany, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Slovenia and Slovakia in breach of them.{{cite web | author=[[European Commission]] | date=2009-07-16 | url=http://ec.europa.eu/economy_finance/the_euro/coins8656_en.htm | title=European Commission â Economic and Financial Affairs â National Sides [ES] | accessdate=2009-07-16 }} The recommendation will be reviewed in 2015. ==Issues== As of January 2011, seventeen countries have independently issued â¬2 commemorative coins ([[Austria]], [[Belgium]], [[Finland]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Greece]], [[Italy]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Malta]], [[Monaco]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Portugal]], [[San Marino]], [[Slovakia]], [[Slovenia]], [[Spain]] and the [[Vatican City]]), with Greece being the first country to issue this type of coin. Three eurozone countries have not yet independently issued such coins ([[Cyprus]], [[Estonia]] and [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]); there have also been two common â¬2 commemorative coin issued by all eurozone member states ([[Treaty of Rome]] in 2007, [[Economic and Monetary Union of the European Union]] in 2009). [[File:European Union commemorative 2 euro coins.png|thumb|alt=A map of Europe, highlighting the member countries of the eurozone and whether they have issued â¬2 commemorative coins or not. The eurozone member countries are most of western Europe south of Denmark, as well as Cyprus, Greece, Finland, Ireland and Malta.| {{legend|#00FF00|has issued â¬2 commemorative coins}} {{legend|#FF0000|has not yet independently issued â¬2 commemorative coins}} {{legend|#CDC3CC|not part of the [[eurozone]]}}]]

Issued designs are made public in the [[Official Journal of the European Union]] (references to these publications are given in the tables below). ===2004 coinage===
{|class="wikitable" |- ! Image !! Country !! Feature !! Volume !! Date |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:2 â¬ con Grecia 2004-1.jpg|150px|Greece 2004; see adjacent text]]
| style="width:20%;"| {{GRC}} | style="width:40%;"| [[2004 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]] in [[Athens]] 2004 | style="width:20%;"| 50 million coins | style="width:20%;"| 14 March 2004{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2004.01.greece.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2004 â Greece | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' The [[Discobolus]] (a classical [[Greece|Greek]] sculpture by [[Myron]]) is depicted in the centre of the coin. To the left of it is the logo of the Olympic games (''ATHENS 2004'') and the five [[Olympic symbols|Olympic Rings]], while to the right the denomination of the coin is given in Greek (''{{lang|el|2 ÎÎ¥Î¡Î©}}''). The twelve stars of the European Union surround the design. The year mark is split around the star in the bottom centre (''20*04''), and the [[mint mark]] is to the upper left of the statue's head.{{cite journal | title=OJ 2004/C 91/06 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=15 April 2004 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2004/c_091/c_09120040415en00050005.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=2 |
[[File:2 â¬ con Finlandia 2004-1.jpg|150px|Finland 2004; see adjacent text]]
|| {{FIN}} || [[History of the European Union#2004âpresent: recent history|Fifth Enlargement]] of the [[European Union]] in 2004 || 1 million coins || FDI:FDI = first date of issue 1 June 2004
FDC:FDC = first date of circulation 1 July 2004{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2004.02.finland.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2004 â Finland | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' The coin's design resembles a stylised [[column|pillar]] from which ten [[shoot|sprouts]] grow upwards. This is a [[metaphor]]ical theme: The ten sprouts represent the growth of the European Union (i.e., the 2004 enlargement which added ten new member states), while the pillar represents the foundation for the growth. Near the bottom of the coin, below the pillar, the word ''EU'' is written, and together with the right side of the pillar, representing the Greek small letter [[Rho (letter)|"Ï" (rho)]], it reads "euro". The twelve stars of the European Union adorn the outer ring together with the year mark, which is at the top of the ring.{{cite journal | title=OJ 2004/C 243/03 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=30 September 2004 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2004/c_243/c_24320040930en00030003.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=2 |
[[File:2 â¬ con Luxemburgo 2004-1.jpg|150px|Luxembourg 2004; see adjacent text]]
|| {{LUX}} || [[Effigy]] and [[Monogram]] of [[Henri, Grand Duke of Luxembourg|Grand Duke Henri]] || 2.49 million coins || 23 June 2004{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2004.03.luxembourg.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2004 â Luxembourg | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' On the left side of the centre part of the coin, the effigy of Grand Duke Henri is depicted, looking to the right. The right side displays his monogram (the letter '''H''' topped with a crown). The twelve stars of the European Union are also on the right side of the inner part, surrounding the monogram in a semicircular form. The year mark, the mint mark and the [[Engraving|engraver]]'s initials are written in circular shape at the top of the outer ring, together with the word ''{{lang|lb|LÃTZEBUERG}}'' ("Luxembourg" in [[Luxembourgish language|Luxembourgish]]), while the words ''{{lang|fr|HENRI â Grand-Duc de Luxembourg}}'' appear at the bottom of the ring.{{cite journal | title=OJ 2004/C 243/05 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=30 September 2004 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2004/c_243/c_24320040930en00060006.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=2 |
[[File:Italia2004.jpg|150px|Italy 2004; see adjacent text]]
|| {{ITA}} || Fifth Decade of the [[World Food Programme]] || 16 million coins || 15 December 2004{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2004.04.italy.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2004 â Italy | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' In the centre of the coin is a [[globe]], tilted to the right. Three [[cereal|ears]] emerge from behind the globe, reaching out to cross the outer ring; these are [[maize]], [[rice]] and [[wheat]], representing the world's basic sources of [[nutrition|nourishment]]. The letters ''R'' and ''I'', superimposed over one another, are to the right of the globe (representing ''[[Italy|Repubblica Italiana]]''), and below them are the [[Engraving|engraver]]'s ([[Uliana Pernazza]]) initials (a combination of the letters ''U'' and ''P''). The mint mark (''R'') is to the upper left of the globe, the year mark is below it, and the twelve stars of the European Union surround the design on the outer ring, grouped into three batches of four stars each, separated by the three ears.{{cite journal | title=OJ 2004/C 313/03 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=18 December 2004 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2004/c_313/c_31320041218en00030003.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=2 |
[[File:2 â¬ con San Marino 2004-1.jpg|150px|San Marino 2004; see adjacent text]]
|| {{SMR}} || [[Bartolomeo Borghesi]] || 110,000 coins || 15 December 2004{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2004.05.sanmarino.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2004 â San Marino | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' The central piece of this coin is a [[bust (sculpture)|bust]] of the famous [[historian]] and [[numismatics|numismatist]] [[Bartolomeo Borghesi]]. It is surrounded by numerous inscriptions in the centre of the coin: ''SAN MARINO'' to the right of the bust, ''BARTOLOMEO BORGHESI'', the mint mark (''R'') and the [[Engraving|engraver]]'s initials (''E.L.F.'') to the left of it. On the outer ring, the coin displays the twelve stars of the European Union and the year mark (bottom centre).{{cite journal | title=OJ 2004/C 298/02 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=3 December 2004 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2004/c_298/c_29820041203en00020002.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=2 |
[[File:2 â¬ con Ciudad del Vaticano 2004-1.jpg|150px|Vatican City 2004; see adjacent text]]
|| {{VAT}} || 75th Anniversary of the [[Lateran treaties|Foundation of the Vatican City State]] || 85,000 coins || 15 December 2004{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2004.06.vaticancity.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2004 â Vatican | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' The central part of the coin depicts a schematic representation of the perimeter walls of the Vatican City with [[St. Peter's Basilica]] in the foreground, together with the [[inscription]]s ''{{lang|it|75o ANNO DELLO STATO}}'' (to the left), ''1929â2004'' and the mint mark (''R'') (both to the right). In addition to these, the name of the designer (''VEROI'') and the initials of the engraver (''L.D.S. INC.'') are written in the lower right in smaller print. The outer ring is adorned by the twelve stars of the European Union and the inscription ''{{lang|it|CITTÃ DEL VATICANO}}''.{{cite journal | title=OJ 2004/C 321/03 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=28 December 2004 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2004/c_321/c_32120041228en00030003.pdf | format=PDF }} |}

| style="width:20%;"| {{LUX}} | style="width:40%;"| 50th [[Birthday]] of [[Henri, Grand Duke of Luxembourg|Grand Duke Henri]], 5th Anniversary of his Accession to the Throne and 100th [[Anniversary]] of the [[Death]] of [[Adolphe, Grand Duke of Luxembourg|Grand Duke Adolphe]] | style="width:20%;"| 2.8 million coins | style="width:20%;"| 15 January 2005{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2005.01.luxembourg.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2005 â Luxembourg | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' In the centre of the coin, the effigies of the Grand Dukes Henri and Adolphe are displayed, both looking to the right, with Henri's superimposed on Adolphe's. The inscription ''{{lang|fr|GRANDS-DUCS DE LUXEMBOURG}}'' appears above the effigies, while the inscriptions ''HENRI *1955'' and ''ADOLPHE â 1905'' are written below the respective effigies. The outer ring of the coin contains the twelve stars of the European Union, placed between the letters of the word ''{{lang|be|LÃTZEBUERG}}'' and the year mark, which is centred below the effigies positioned between ''S'' (for [[Finland|Suomi]]) on the left and the mint mark on the right.{{cite journal | title = OJ 2005/C 11/03 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union | date=15 January 2005 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2005/c_011/c_01120050115en00030003.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:â¬2 commemorative coin Belgium 2005.gif|150px|Belgium 2006; see adjacent text]]
|| {{BEL}} || [[Belgium-Luxembourg Economic Union]] || 6 million coins || FDI: 1 March 2005
FDC: 1 April 2005{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2005.02.belgium.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2005 â Belgium | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' In the centre of the coin, the [[effigy|effigies]] of [[Henri, Grand Duke of Luxembourg|Grand Duke Henri of Luxembourg]] and [[Albert II of Belgium|King Albert II of the Belgians]] are depicted, looking left. The engraver's initials (''LL'') are in the lower right, while the year mark is below the effigies. On the outer circle, the twelve stars of the European Union are displayed, along with the mint mark on the bottom, the monogram of Grand-Duke Henri to the left and the monogram of King Albert II to the right.{{cite journal | title=OJ 2005/C 61/08 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=11 March 2005 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2005/c_061/c_06120050311en00070007.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:2 â¬ con EspaÃ±a 2005-1.jpg|150px|Spain 2006; see adjacent text]]
|| {{ESP}} || 4th [[Centenary]] of the first [[edition]] of [[Miguel de Cervantes]]' [[Don Quixote|''El ingenioso hidalgo Don Quixote de la Mancha'']] || 8 million coins || 1 April 2005{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2005.04.spain.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2005 â Spain | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' The centre of the coin displays [[Don Quixote]] holding a [[lance]], with the [[windmill]]s from one of his most well-known escapades in the background. The inscription ''{{lang|es|ESPAÃA}}'' is impressed into the surface of the coin to the left of the image, with the mint mark (an ''M'' topped by a [[Crown (headgear)|crown]]) below. The twelve stars of the European Union are placed on the outer ring, with the four on the right side impressed into the surface of the coin, as well, and the year mark placed between three of the stars (''*20*05*'') at the bottom.{{cite journal | title=OJ 2005/C 131/09 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=28 May 2005 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2005/c_131/c_13120050528en00090009.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:2 â¬ con Austria 2005-1.jpg|150px|Austria 2006; see adjacent text]]
|| {{AUT}} || 50th Anniversary of the [[Austrian State Treaty]] || 7 million coins || 11 May 2005{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2005.03.austria.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2005 â Austria | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' In the centre of the coin is a depiction of the seals and signatures of the Austrian State Treaty, signed by the [[foreign minister]]s of the [[Allies of World War II|Allied occupying forces]] ([[Vyacheslav Molotov]] for the [[Soviet Union]], [[John Foster Dulles]] for the [[United States]], [[Harold Macmillan]] for the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Antoine Pinay]] for [[France]]), the [[High Commissioner]]s of the four sectors, as well as the [[Foreign Minister of Austria]] ([[Leopold Figl]]) on 15 May 1955. The inscription ''{{lang|de|50 JAHRE STAATSVERTRAG}}'' is above the seals, while the year mark is below it; in the background, [[Gules|vertical stripes]] serve as a [[heraldry|heraldic]] depiction of Austria's [[Flag of Austria|national flag]] ([[red]]-[[white]]-red). The outer ring contains the twelve stars of the European Union.{{cite journal | title=OJ 2005/C 61/07 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=11 March 2005 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2005/c_061/c_06120050311en00060006.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:2 â¬ con San Marino 2005-1.jpg|150px|San Marino 2006; see adjacent text]]
|| {{SMR}} || [[World Year of Physics 2005]] || 130,000 coins || 14 October 2005{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2005.05.sanmarino.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2005 â San Marino | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' The centre of the coin contains a free [[interpretation (aesthetics)|interpretation]] of the [[allegory|allegorical]] painting of [[Galileo Galilei]] known as ''[[La fisica antica]]'' or ''[[The Study of the Planets]]''. The year mark is inscribed below a [[globe]] standing on a [[desk]]. The mint mark (''R'') is to the left of the image, while the engraverâs initials (''LDS'') appear on the right. The inscription ''SAN MARINO'' is aligned in a [[semicircle]] above the image, while the inscription ''{{lang|it|ANNO MONDIALE DELLA FISICA}}'' forms another semicircle below it. The outer ring bears the twelve stars of the European Union which are separated by the outer edges of a stylised atom depicted in the background of the entire coin.{{cite journal | title=OJ 2005/C 244/03 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=4 October 2005 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2005/c_244/c_24420051004en00030003.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:2 â¬ con Finlandia 2005 A.jpg|150px|Finland 2006; see adjacent text]]
|| {{FIN}} || 60th Anniversary of the Establishment of the [[United Nations]] and 50th Anniversary of Finland's UN Membership || 2 million coins || 25 October 2005{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2005.06.finland.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2005 â Finland | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' The centre of the coin contains part of a [[jigsaw puzzle]] showing a [[Peace symbol|dove of peace]]. On the bottom of the centre part, the inscription ''FINLAND â UN'' and the year mark is displayed; the artist's initial (''K'') appears above the last digit of the year mark, while the mint mark (''M'') is between the inscription and the dove. The twelve stars of the European Union adorn the outer ring.{{cite journal | title=OJ 2005/C 244/04 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=4 October 2005 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2005/c_244/c_24420051004en00040004.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:2 â¬ con Italia 2005-1.jpg|150px|Italy 2006; see adjacent text]]
|| {{ITA}} || 1st Anniversary of the Signing of the [[European Constitution]] || 18 million coins || 29 October 2005{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2005.07.italy.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2005 â Italy | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' The centre of the coin features [[Europa (mythology)|Europa]] and the bull ([[Zeus]]), together with the European Constitution; Europa is holding a pen over it, symbolising its signing. The mint mark (''R'') is to the upper left of the image, the engraver's ([[Maria Carmela Colaneri]]) initials (''MCC'') to the lower left, and the year mark is to the upper right. The [[monogram]] of the Italian Republic (''RI'') is at the bottom of the centre part, slightly to the left. The outer ring features the inscription ''{{lang|it|COSTITUZIONE EUROPEA}}'', forming almost a full [[semicircle]], while the remainder of the outer ring is taken up by the twelve stars of the European Union.{{cite journal | title=OJ 2005/C 283/06 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=16 November 2005 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2005/c_283/c_28320051116en00170017.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"|
[[File:2005vat.jpg|150px|Vatican City 2006; see adjacent text]]
|| {{VAT}} || [[World Youth Day 2005|20th World Youth Day]], held in [[Cologne]] in August 2005 || 100,000 coins || 6 December 2005{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2005.08.vaticancity.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2005 â Vatican | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' The centre of the coin contains the [[Cologne Cathedral]] and a [[comet]] passing by above it. The inscription ''{{lang|it|XX GIORNATA MONDIALE DELLA GIOVENTÃ}}'' is written in the upper part of the centre, separated by the tail of the comet and two of the [[cathedral]]'s [[spire]]s, one of which extends into the outer ring. The outer ring contains the inscription ''{{lang|it|CITTÃ DEL VATICANO}}'' in the lower half and the twelve stars of the European Union in the upper half, with the year mark and the mint mark (''R'') separating them in the top centre.{{cite journal | title=OJ 2005/C 283/07 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union|date=16 November 2005 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2005/c_283/c_28320051116en00180018.pdf | format=PDF }} |}

The twelve stars of the European Union surround the design on the outer ring of the coin.{{cite journal | title = OJ 2006/C 33/05 | journal = Official Journal of the European Union|date = 9 February 2006 | url = http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2006/c_033/c_03320060209en00060006.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"|

The designer's initials (''LL'') are to the left. The letter ''B'' for Belgium is written at the top of the outer ring, and the year mark at the bottom; the twelve stars of the European Union are positioned between the year mark and the inscription at the top, in two groups of six stars each.{{cite journal | title = OJ 2006/C 53/03 | journal = Official Journal of the European Union | date = 3 March 2006 | url = http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2006/c_053/c_05320060303en00030003.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"|

Two capital ''M'''s appear to the left of each face, one of them the mint mark and the other one the artist's initial. On the left side, the date of the introduction of universal and equal suffrage in Finland (''1. 10. 1906'') is inscribed, while the right side of the coin contains the year mark and the country abbreviation (''20 FI 06''). The twelve stars of the European Union surround the design on the outer ring of the coin.{{cite journal | title = OJ 2006/C 248/02 | journal = Official Journal of the European Union | date = 14 October 2006 | url = http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2006/c_248/c_24820061014en00020002.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"|

At the top of the inner part is the inscription ''SAN MARINO'' together with a [[compass rose]], in the centre is the mint mark ''R'', and at the bottom is a [[cartouche]] containing the inscription ''1506â2006'' and the initials of the designer (''LDS''). The twelve stars of the European Union surround the design on the outer ring of the coin.{{cite journal | title = OJ 2006/C 248/03 | journal = Official Journal of the European Union | date = 14 October 2006 | url = http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2006/c_248/c_24820061014en00030003.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"| [[File:2 â¬ con Ciudad del Vaticano 2006-1.jpg|150px|Vatican City 2006; see adjacent text]] || {{VAT}} || 500th Anniversary of the [[Swiss Guard]] || 100,000 coins || 9 November 2006{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.2006.07.vaticancity.htm | title=The Euro â â¬2 Commemorative Design 2006 â Vatican | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} |- | colspan="5" | '''Description:''' The centre part of the coin features a member of the Swiss Guard taking his oath on the flag of the Swiss Guard, facing the right side. In the top part of the inner circle, the inscription ''GUARDIA SVIZZERA PONTIFICIA'' surrounds the guard, while the bottom part carries the inscription ''CITTÃ DEL VATICANO''. The guard is surrounded by four other inscriptions, with the year ''1506'' and the signature of the designer ''O. ROSSI'' to his left and the year mark ''2006'' and the mint mark ''R'' to his right. The twelve stars of the European Union surround the design on the outer ring of the coin.{{cite journal | title = OJ 2006/C 260/06 | journal = Official Journal of the European Union | date = 28 October 2006 | url = http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2006/c_260/c_26020061028en00110011.pdf | format=PDF }} |}

|| colspan=2 | {{ESP}} || colspan=2 | 8 million coins |- | colspan="4" | '''Inscription:''' ''{{lang|es|TRATADO DE ROMA 50 AÃOS}}'', ''{{lang|es|EUROPA}}'', ''{{lang|es|ESPAÃA}}'' |- | colspan="6" | Due to special laws requiring that every coin bear the incumbent Grand Duke's portrait, the Luxembourgish edition of the common â¬2 commemorative coin differs slightly from the others in addition to the translated inscriptions, since a latent image of the Grand Duke's portrait was added (as required by national law) using a technique called [[multi-view minting]].{{cite web | date=2007-03-23 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/files/files.c2e/2e.tor.09.luxembourg.htm | title=The Euro Information Website- 2 Euro Treaty of Rome 50th Anniversary Commemorative Design- Luxembourg | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} A similar Dutch law, which requires the portrait of the current head of state of the Netherlands and the words ''{{lang|nl|NAME (Koning/Koningin) der Nederlanden}}'' to appear on all coins issued by the Netherlands (for example, currently ''{{lang|nl|[[Beatrix of the Netherlands|Beatrix Koningin der Nederlanden]]}}'') was amended so that the Netherlands could take part in this program; the amendment completely removed the requirement for â¬2 commemorative coins. Furthermore, due to Belgium's special multilingual society, the Belgian coin features the inscription ''{{lang|la|PACTVM ROMANVM QVINQVAGENARIVM}}'' in [[Latin]]. The three micro-states which also use the euro due to an official agreement with the European Union ([[Monaco]], [[San Marino]] and the [[Vatican City]]) did not issue this coin, as they are not member states of the European Union. However, some member states of the European Union which had not yet introduced the euro also took part in this program. For example, [[Cyprus]] issued a [[Cypriot pound|Â£1 coin]] and [[Hungary]] a [[Hungarian forint|50 Ft coin]] with the same design. |}

Above the portrait is the inscription ''LOUIS BRAILLE'', and underneath is the inscription ''BE'' between the dates 1809 and 2009. To the left and right respectively are the mint mark and the mint master mark. The twelve stars of the European Union surround the design on the outer ring of the coin.{{cite journal | title = OJ 2009/C 196/06 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union | date=20 August 2009 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2009/c_196/c_19620090820en00060006.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"|

Above the index finger, which is pointing at the vertical inscription ''LOUIS BRAILLE 1809â2009'', are two birds symbolising freedom of knowledge. The issuing country reference ''RI'' is at the top right, while the mint mark ''R'' is at the bottom right. Braille's name is written under the book in the [[Braille alphabet]] that he invented. At the very bottom are the initials ''MCC'' of the artist [[Maria Carmela ColanÃ©ri]]. The twelve stars of the European Union surround the design on the outer ring of the coin.{{cite journal | title = OJ 2009/C 196/08 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union | date=20 August 2009 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2009/c_196/c_19620090820en00080008.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"|

NOVEMBER SLOBODA â DEMOKRACIA'' and the dates ''1989â2009'' and below by the name of the issuing country ''SLOVENSKO''. The twelve stars of the European Union surround the design on the outer ring of the coin.{{cite journal | title = OJ 2009/C 196/07 | journal=Official Journal of the European Union | date=20 August 2009 | url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/site/en/oj/2009/c_196/c_19620090820en00070007.pdf | format=PDF }} |- | colspan="5" |   |- | style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"|

The design is surrounded on the bottom left-hand side by the legend ''ANNO INTERNAZIONALE DELLÂ´ASTRONOMIA'' and on the top right-hand side by the name of the issuing country ''CITTÃ DEL VATICANO''. ===German BundeslÃ¤nder series=== [[Germany]] started the commemorative coin series ''{{lang|de|Die 16 BundeslÃ¤nder der Bundesrepublik Deutschland}}'' (The 16 [[States of Germany|States]] of the Federal Republic of Germany) in 2006, which will continue until 2021. The year in which the coin for a specific state is issued coincides with that state's [[President of the German Bundesrat|Presidency]] of the [[Bundesrat of Germany|''Bundesrat'']].{{cite web | date=2007-04-07 | url=http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/InformationWebsite.htm?http://www.ibiblio.org/theeuro/faq.htm#BundeslanderSeries | title=The Euro â FAQ: ''BundeslÃ¤nder'' Series | accessdate=2007-04-07 }} The coins issued are:

The series is similar to the [[United States]]' [[50 State Quarters]] series, which saw fifty coins issued for its fifty constituent states, five per year between 1999 and 2008. A separate program saw six coins issued in 2009 for the [[District of Columbia]] and five [[territories of the United States]]. ===Maltese constitutional history series=== Malta started a series of five â¬2 commemorative coins, all related to the Maltese constitutional history. The first coin was released in 2011 and the last coin will be minted in 2015.http://ec.europa.eu/economy_finance/euro/cash/commemorative/2011_en.htm It is likely that the 4th coin, which will be released in 2014, will commemorate 50th anniversary of Malta's [[Malta#Independence and Republic|constitution]]. {| class="wikitable" style="margin:auto;" |- ! Year !! Number !! Design |- | 2011 || style="text-align:center; font-size:10px;"| 1 || First Election of Representatives in 1849 |}

===Spanish UNESCO World Heritage Sites series=== [[Spain]] started the commemorative coin series ''{{lang|es|Patrimonio de la Humanidad de la UNESCO}}'' (UNESCO World Heritage) in 2010, commemorating all of Spain's [[UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Spain|UNESCO World Heritage Sites]], which could continue until 2050.
